we have dev techniques like testing to limit the chances of bugs, but the ultimate question

Will it work on production ?

and in the past our prod was fairly easily to to set up locally and test it.
productive developers.
easy to reason.
easy to navigate.
but web was growing
as an industry we quickly learned this approach won't handle web scale easily.
but also with growing teams development became harder
solved a lot of problems of monolithic arch, but introduces another challenges.
  • The network is reliable
  • Latency is zero
  • Bandwidth is infinite
  • Transport cost is zero
    •    https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fallacies_of_distributed_computing
we took a lot of things for granted from monolithic approach. bandwith - it improved but it still is way slower than local memory. transport cost- Serialization and deserialization consume CPU time, so it costs money.
we want to be fast
  • $ mvn clean install

  • $ kubectl|oc apply humongous.yaml

Let me share you the real life story
SaaS dev tooling
from idea to prod
  • Lots of moving pieces
  • Blocked PRs
  • Problematic staging cluster
  • Desire for local developer experience


And what about prod?

we were obviously breaking prod way too often

Staging environment

  • Challenging to keep in-sync with prod
  • Extra costs
  • Uncertainty
we had staging cluster - it gave us a bit more confidence than any local level of testing, but... Q: who has such a setup? Happy with it?
our productivity suffered. people were frustrated and didn't feel like they are delivering any value. angry -- leaving

Goals


Easily validate your changes without interfering other services and users

Interact with other services in the cluster

Write software locally using your favorite tools
so we started little research
rh openshift - k8s distro with enterprise grade features
building block. targets given pod. we still need orchestration to create new versions of services
who heard?
two pillars - data plane (intelligent proxy) and control plane. externalizing infra aspects - location / access rights / failover. you can focus on business logic

Security

who can call who. strong identity, powerful policy, transparent TLS encryption, and authentication, authorization and audit (AAA) tools to protect your services and data

Metrics

by prometheus http and tcp by default - size, amount, open / closed tcp connections

Failure Recovery

timeouts and retries
circuit breakers. resilence4j / hystrix - but why?

Traffic Mirroring

dark launches - so that new version gets the same traffic. mention Diffy

Traffic Splitting

that was the most important thing for us - to have easy way of deciding who can hit our version of the service
